item.title: Japan Touts Progress in US Trade Talks With Eyes on June Summit
item.description: Japan’s top trade negotiator Ryosei Akazawa said the latest round of discussions with the Trump administration on tariffs have them on track toward a deal as early as next month, while refraining from citing specifics.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara, Ryan Chua

media:content.media:description: A shipping terminal in Yokohama, Japan.

item.title: Trump Sees Xi Call Settling Trade Flap Over Rare Earth Exports
item.description: US President Donald Trump expressed confidence a talk with Chinese President Xi Jinping could ease fresh trade tensions, after White House officials vented anger over Beijing’s pace of issuing promised export licenses.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer A Dlouhy

media:content.media:description: A container ship approaches the Yangshan Deepwater Port in Shanghai.

item.title: US Consumers Hit the Brakes While Goods Imports Sink by a Record
item.description: US consumers hit the brakes in April while goods imports plummeted by a record as companies adjusted to higher tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Augusta Saraiva

media:content.media:description: Shoppers at a store in the Brooklyn borough of New York. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: Tariff Revenues Rise Sharply in Canada After Retaliation Against Trump Levies
item.description: A spike in custom import duties shows proceeds from retaliatory tariffs are starting to roll into the coffers of Canada’s federal government.
item.dc:creator: Erik Hertzberg

media:content.media:description: Trucks at the Canada-US border in Fort Erie, Ontario.

item.title: Brazil’s Economy Surges, Keeping Central Bankers Wary on Interest Rates
item.description: Brazil’s economy leaped forward at the start of 2025 on gains across several key sectors, likely making it more difficult for the central bank to end its increases to sky-high interest rates.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Rosati, Martha Viotti Beck

item.title: Ukraine to Skip $665 Million Payment on Growth-Linked Debt
item.description: Ukraine said it’s skipping a $665 million payment on government debt linked to economic growth after the country failed to agree on restructuring terms with a group of creditors led by hedge funds.
item.dc:creator: Daryna Krasnolutska

media:content.media:description: Volodymyr Zelenskiy

item.title: US Tax on Foreign Money Is Power Play, Commerzbank Analyst Says
item.description: A proposed measure in Donald Trump’s flagship tax-and-spending bill is a sign that the US administration is exploring new tools to force other countries to bend to its will, according to Ulrich Leuchtmann, head of FX research at Commerzbank AG.
item.dc:creator: Alice Gledhill

media:content.media:description: The White House in Washington, DC, US, on Saturday, May 10, 2025. The legislative push for President Donald Trump's massive tax package will begin in earnest next week as key House committees consider the legislation despite lingering divisions among Republicans.

item.title: Rich Nations Courted by Zimbabwe Non-Committal on $2.6 Billion Bridge Finance
item.description: Zimbabwe hasn’t received any concrete commitments of financial support from 10 nations it appealed to for help in its long-standing efforts to clear debt arrears.
item.dc:creator: Katarina Hoije, Ray Ndlovu

media:content.media:description: Mthuli Ncube, Zimbabwe's finance minister, during a panel session at the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos, Switzerland, on Wednesday, Jan. 22, 2025. The annual Davos gathering of political leaders, top executives and celebrities runs from January 20 to 24.

item.title: Kenya’s Low Inflation May Mask Deeper Economic Strain, Analysts Warn
item.description: Kenya’s sustained low inflation rate may be a sign of a struggling economy, analysts warned, casting doubt on policymakers’ contentions that slowing price growth is down to effective policy.
item.dc:creator: David Herbling

media:content.media:description: An employee talks to customers inside a tech store in downtown Nairobi, Kenya.

item.title: Erdogan Backs Turkey Economy Plan But Repeats Distaste for Rates
item.description: Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdogan reiterated his opposition to interest rates while endorsing the country’s orthodox economic program, which relies on high borrowing costs to curb inflation.
item.dc:creator: Beril Akman, Firat Kozok

media:content.media:description: Recep Tayyip Erdogan

item.title: Mozambique Extends Record Rate-Cutting Streak as Inflation Cools
item.description: Mozambique’s central bank lowered its benchmark interest rate for a record 9th consecutive time, with inflation set to remain in the single digits.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Hill, Tavares Cebola

media:content.media:description: Maputo.

item.title: US Consumer Sentiment Recovers in Final May Michigan Survey
item.description: US consumer sentiment rebounded in late May from one of the lowest readings on record earlier in the month and long-term inflation expectations retreated as concerns about the economy eased after the rollback of China tariffs.
item.dc:creator: Nazmul Ahasan

media:content.media:description: A shopper in San Francisco.

item.title: Looming BOE Decision Casts £4 Billion Shadow Over UK’s Budget
item.description: A decision that the Bank of England has to make in the next few months is posing a £4.3 billion ($5.8 billion) threat to Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves’ spending plans.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick, Greg Ritchie

item.title: India’s Economy Beats Forecast on Strong Investments
item.description: India’s economy grew at a faster pace than analysts expected last quarter, driven by a rebound in investments and strong services sector activity, though risks persist amid shifting global trade dynamics.
item.dc:creator: Anup Roy, Prateek Mazumdar

media:content.media:description: A metalsmith welds a part of pontoon bridge at a workshop in Prayagraj, India. Photographer: Sanjay Kanojia/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: Canada GDP Grows 2.2% in First Quarter, Beats All Forecasts
item.description: A strong jump in tariff-driven exports fueled Canada’s growth at the start of this year, offsetting domestic weakness in other parts of the economy.
item.dc:creator: Randy Thanthong-Knight

media:content.media:description: Heavy haulers at the Fort Hills mine on the Athabasca oil sands near Fort McMurray, Alberta.

item.title: German Inflation Slows Less Than Expected With ECB Set to Cut
item.description: German inflation slowed less than expected, highlighting lingering risks as the European Central Bank prepares to lower interest rates again.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow

media:content.media:description: Germany's consumer prices rose an annual 2.1% in May.

item.title: Tariff Ruling Threatens a $2 Trillion Fiscal Hole in Trump Plan
item.description: The court ruling that blocked much of President Donald Trump’s sweeping tariffs threatens to blow what some economists estimate as a $2 trillion hole into the US fiscal outlook over the coming decade, should the judgment stay in place.
item.dc:creator: Enda Curran, Alicia Diaz

media:content.media:description: The U.S. Treasury Department building in front of the White House.

item.title: Trump Tariffs Have US Eateries Rethinking That Dutch Gouda
item.description: For decades, American restaurants have largely taken for granted that imported foods would be readily available at reasonable prices, thanks to decades of globalization and free trade.
item.dc:creator: Daniela Sirtori

media:content.media:description: The charcuterie board at Sysco's test kitchen featuring items such as salami from Chicago Salumi and a camembert from New York.

item.title: Trade Court Battle Upends Trump Tariff Plan, Clouding Economic Outlook
item.description: I’m Cécile Daurat, manager of the US economy team. Today we’re looking at the economic implications of the legal fight over tariffs. Send us feedback and tips to ecodaily@bloomberg.net. And if you aren’t yet signed up to receive this newsletter, you can do so here.
item.dc:creator: Cecile Daurat

item.title: Trump’s Tax Bill Has Nasty Surprise in SALT Fine Print for Some Rich Americans
item.description: House Republicans’ “big, beautiful bill” could bring hundreds of billions of dollars in tax cuts to wealthy business owners.
item.dc:creator: Ben Steverman

media:content.media:description: US House Speaker Mike Johnson, a Republican from Louisiana, right, and US President Donald Trump after attending a House Republican caucus meeting at the US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Tuesday, May 20, 2025. Trump on Tuesday pushed back on demands from Republicans who have threatened to sink his giant tax bill if the legislation does not significantly boost the state and local tax deduction, lawmakers said.

item.title: Zambia Proposes Increased Number of Lawmakers as Elections Loom
item.description: Zambia plans to boost the number of elected members of parliament by more than a third, raising the prospect of a higher government wage bill at a time when the state is trying to conclude a debt-restructuring process.
item.dc:creator: Taonga Mitimingi

media:content.media:description: Hakainde Hichilema Photographer: Bernd von Jutrczenka/picture alliance/Getty Images

item.title: Sweden’s Surprise Economic Contraction Boosts Rate Cut Odds
item.description: An unexpected economic contraction in Sweden boosted expectations that the Riksbank will cut interest rates over the summer to support a rebound in output.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Duxbury

media:content.media:description: A factory floor in Sweden.

item.title: Inflation Dips Below 2% in Italy and Spain, Backing ECB Cut
item.description: Inflation in Italy and Spain eased to just below the European Central Bank’s 2% target, backing the case for interest rates to be lowered again next week.
item.dc:creator: Daniel Basteiro

media:content.media:description: Spain's consumer prices rose 1.9% from a year ago in May. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg

item.title: ECB’s Panetta Suggests Inflation Is Almost Defeated in Euro Zone
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Fabio Panetta signaled that inflation is nearly fully tamed, while cautioning that further interest-rate cuts require finely balanced judgments.
item.dc:creator: Flavia Rotondi, Alessandra Migliaccio, Sonia Sirletti

media:content.media:description: Fabio Panetta on May 30. Photographer: Alessia Pierdomenico/Bloomberg

item.title: Turkey’s Economy Cools at Start of Year Despite Rate Cuts
item.description: Turkey’s economy cooled in the first quarter as high interest rates continued to weigh on activity despite a trio of early cuts by the central bank.
item.dc:creator: Beril Akman

media:content.media:description: Shoppers at the Mahmutpasha market in Istanbul. Photographer: Kerem Uzel/Bloomberg

item.title: Reform UK Chair Dismisses Worries About Cost of Tax, Spend Plans
item.description: The chair of Reform UK dismissed concerns that its plans to cut taxes and increase welfare benefits would rattle the bond market, casting the moves as part of a broader plan to “modernize the economy and get it growing again.”
item.dc:creator: Lucy White, William Selway

media:content.media:description: Zia Yusuf

item.title: UK Business Confidence Hits 9-Month High in Boost for Labour
item.description: A gauge of UK business confidence rose to a nine-month high, climbing back to a level not seen since soon after Prime Minister Keir Starmer first took power, as markets rebounded and trade tensions eased with the US.
item.dc:creator: Irina Anghel

item.title: BOE’s Bailey Urges Closer EU Trade to Reverse Brexit Damage
item.description: Bank of England Governor Andrew Bailey urged the government to strike a deeper trade deal with the European Union to improve growth and “minimize negative effects” of Brexit.
item.dc:creator: Philip Aldrick, Tom Rees, Irina Anghel, Francine Lacqua

media:content.media:description: Andrew Bailey, governor of the Bank of England (BOE), at the Monetary Policy Report news conference at the bank's headquarters in the City of London, UK, on Thursday, May 8, 2025. The Bank of England cut interest rates by a quarter point to 4.25% as Donald Trump’s global trade war weighs on UK growth, in a decision that split senior officials into three groups and was made before the US President hinted at an imminent deal to lower tariffs on British exports.

item.title: Kenyan Inflation Stays Below 5% for Longest Run in 15 Years
item.description: Kenyan annual inflation remained below the 5% midpoint of the central bank’s target range for a 12th straight month, the longest stretch since at least 2010, strengthening the case for another interest-rate cut.
item.dc:creator: David Herbling

media:content.media:description: Street vendors sell second-hand clothing on a shopping street in downtown Nairobi, Kenya, on Saturday, Dec. 5, 2020. Kenya is seeking a loan of as much as $2.3 billion from the International Monetary Fund under the lender’s extended fund facility. Photographer: Fredrik Lerneryd/Bloomberg

item.title: France Inks Deal With Singapore as Macron Courts Southeast Asia
item.description: France and Singapore signed a wide-ranging deal to enhance nuclear power and clean energy cooperation during President Emmanuel Macron’s visit to the city-state.
item.dc:creator: Philip Heijmans, Josh Xiao, Clara Ferreira Marques

media:content.media:description: France's President Emmanuel Macron speaks at a press briefing with Singapore's Prime Minister Lawrence Wong in Singapore on May 30, 2025. (Photo by Ludovic MARIN / AFP) (Photo by LUDOVIC MARIN/AFP via Getty Images)
